Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. No
substantial violations were found.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12404 Placement.
Section (1) An agency shall only place a child with an adult who is legally
Description related to the child, is a legal custodian, or in a licensed foster
home, except as permitted in R 400.12709.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency is using an unlicensed, non-relative placement for a foster
youth.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Foster Care Worker was interviewed via Teams on 4/13/2023.
She reported Parent A gave birth to Youth A in November of 2022
after which Youth A was immediately placed with a teacher at the
school, Caregiver A, where Parent A’s other children attend
daycare. This placement was made prior to Youth A being placed
in foster care and Parent A signed a document with DHHS stating
she agreed to the placement. Youth A entered the foster care
system in January of 2023 at which time he remained placed in
the home of Caregiver A in which he was already living as a fictive
kin placement.
Parent A/Complainant was interviewed by phone on 4/14/2023.
Parent A reported she signed a safety plan with DHHS while she
was in the hospital after giving birth to Youth A. This safety plan
indicated Youth A would be placed with Caregiver A as Parent A
did not have anywhere for the youth to live. She stated she
thought Caregiver A had a foster home license, but now thinks
she does not.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
• Initial Safety Screen for Caregiver A completed 11/28/2022
and 1/10/2023.
• Preliminary home study of Caregiver A completed
1/10/2023.
• Court Orders
o Youth A placed in foster care on 1/17/2023.
o 2/13/2023 adjournment due to Parent A being
AWOL.
2

o 3/28/2023 preliminary hearing ordering continuation
of current placement.
• MiSACWIS placement history – Youth A placed with
Caregiver A on 1/17/2023.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance due to Youth A having lived
with Caregiver A since birth, which was two months prior to entry
into foster care, thus meeting the definition of relative at the time
the foster care case was opened.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
Section (1) An agency shall develop service plans with the child, the child’s
Description parents or legal guardian, the referring agency, and other parties
involved in providing needed services, or medical care, unless the
agency documents why any of the entities have not been involved.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency has not informed parent of her service plan.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Foster Care Worker was interviewed via Teams on 4/13/2023.
She reported she has worked with Parent A for approximately 2
years during which time she had her rights terminated to 3 youth,
the most recent occurring in February of 2023, due to a lack of
participation and compliance with services. Foster Care Worker
reported Parent A has been homeless and AWOL throughout the
two years and has provided multiple addresses and phone
numbers. Since Youth A entered foster care in January, Foster
Care Worker has tried to contact Parent A at least a couple of
times a month, if not weekly. She reported she has recently
increased her efforts to nearly daily. Foster Care Worker reported
most of the texts she has sent to Parent A have not received a
response; however, at the end of March 2023, Parent A reached
out to her with a new phone number, after which Parent A has
increased her responsiveness. Foster Care Worker stated Parent
A is aware of the services in which she is supposed to be
engaged as those services have remained consistent. Foster Care
Worker stated Parent A does not have a copy of Youth A’s initial
service plan as when it was mailed to the address provided by
Parent A, it was returned to sender as “undeliverable.” Foster
Care Worker reported she has notified Parent A of court dates
through text messages, but Parent A has not attended.
3

Parent A/Complainant was interviewed by phone on 4/14/2023.
She reported Foster Care Worker has not been responsive to her
text messages until the past couple of weeks. Parent A stated
Foster Care Worker had her previous phone number and she
provided Foster Care Worker with her new number recently. She
stated Foster Care Worker has only responded to her texts twice
since Youth A was born. Parent A stated she has never been
informed of court dates or her treatment plan. Parent A reported
she attempted to call Foster Care Worker once, but she did not
answer. Parent A reported she has been homeless, but she had
provided Foster Care Worker with an address where her mail can
be sent, and she was unaware there were issues with her mail be
undeliverable. Parent A stated she is recovering from a bacterial
infection, and she has been sick for a few months, so there have
been times she didn’t make it to appointments. Parent A stated
she would like to work toward reunification but feels Foster Care
Worker is not making any effort because Parent A’s rights were
terminated for her other children. Parent A stated she has been
sending texts to Foster Care Worker since Youth A was born and
would be providing copies of her unanswered texts; however,
these texts were never provided.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
• Court Orders
o Youth A placed in foster care on 1/17/2023.
o 2/13/2023 adjournment due to Parent A being
AWOL.
o 3/28/2023 termination petition authorized due to
Parent A’s lack of participation/progress.
• Case Contacts –
o Multiple documented contacts were reviewed to
which no response was received.
o Text messages to Parent A providing court dates
sent on 2/7/2023, 2/10/2023, 3/11/2023, and
4/10/2023.
o Text messages to Parent A regarding
services/treatment planning sent on 2/7/2023,
3/11/2023, 3/13/2023.
• Email sent to Parent A with Notice of Hearing on 2/28/2023.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance due to documentation that
attempts have been made to contact Parent A to inform her of the
service plan and court dates.
4

Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time.
Section (1) An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and
Description parenting time that contains, at a minimum, all of the following:
(c) Provisions for visits between parents and children except
where parental rights have been terminated or when there is a
court determination that visits are detrimental to the child.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Parent has not been provided visitation with their child since
12/4/2022.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed via Teams on
4/13/2023. She reported Parent A’s parenting time was
suspended in the case that was already open at the time Youth A
came into care and the court has not ordered parenting time for
Youth A. Foster Care Supervisor has recently transitioned to a
new position at the agency and is no longer assigned to the case.
Foster Care Worker was interviewed via Teams on 4/13/2023.
She reported the court has not ordered parenting time for Parent
A, so she has not seen Youth A since his birth. Foster Care
Worker provided a copy of the recent court order stating parenting
time is suspended for Parent A “until such time as mother avails
herself to the department.” Foster Care Worker stated she was not
at the last hearing, but she will follow-up with her co-worker who
attended the hearing to seek clarification about parenting time.
On 4/24/2023, an email from Foster Care Worker stated the
prosecutor on the case clarified that the agency has discretion to
start parenting time, without a new court order, “If the agency feels
mom is participating in a meaningful way.” Foster Care Worker
wrote that Parent A has not submitted anything related to service
participation since May of 2022 and Parent A is not receptive to
Foster Care Worker’s attempts to obtain her address for a home
visit or Foster Care Worker’s requests for Parent A to meet at the
agency; therefore, parenting time has not been implemented.
Parent A/Complainant was interviewed by phone on 4/14/2023.
She reported she hasn’t seen Youth A since she left the hospital
after giving birth. She reported that she has not been to any of the
court hearings, but Foster Care Worker told her that parenting
time has not been ordered.
5

DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
• Court Orders
o Youth A placed in foster care on 1/17/2023, hearing
adjourned for continuation, parenting time not
addressed.
o 2/13/2023 hearing adjourned.
o 3/28/2023 ordering Parent A’s parenting time
suspended “until such time as mother avails herself
to the department”.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance due to the court order requiring
Parent A to participate in services prior to beginning parenting
time and Parent A’s lack of participation.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
April 24, 2023
